number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
2011
												DO YOU KNOW WHO ATE ALL THE DONUTS?I'm not sure what I can say about Half-Life that hasn't been said already, but I'll try anyway.This was Valve's flagship title, and it's definitely a classic. It was revolutionary in its day - November 1998, to be precise - for its (somewhat) realistic combat and overall approach to its narrative. There were no cutscenes or voiceovers for the main character. You were put into the shoes of Gordon Freeman, PhD. That made the game all the more immersive and involving, and it is indeed both.The plot itself is still very good and elegantly presented, if not entirely as gripping nowadays where half-realistic aliens and gundudes are more prevalent in gaming. The first section of the game involves you commuting to work in a labryinthine government research facility; the presentation and interactivity present during your commute (and preparation for the workday) make it work quite well, and it's still believable.Then you do a big experiment and everything goes to Hell in a handbasket. Hostile aliens are teleporting in from the alternate dimension your employers were foolish enough to screw around with, and you have to fight your way out of the laboratories with a scant few weapons at first. Things only get worse from there.This is primarily a first-person shooter, and the gunplay is good if a bit repetitive. You eventually carry a whole armory's worth of guns, from an MP5 to a rocket launcher to guns that shoot tau and gluon particles (creative license; I'm pretty sure tau and gluon particles can't actually explode people) to an alien bio-gun that shoots angry bees. The graphics...were probably great back when it was released, and while they still seem timeless to me they haven't aged quite as gracefully as Half-Life 2's graphics.There's also a fair bit of puzzling to be had; mostly moving objects around, jumping puzzles and finding the right switch in an area. They're not terribly hard, but they intersperse very nicely with the shooting. Since this game is partially based off the Quake engine, your character moves rather fast by default, which is something to keep in mind.The AI was unprecedented in its day, but not quite as stellar now. They can still put up a good fight though, and the game can become very intense if you're not careful. The music is excellent; a fitting mix of unsettling ambient electronica and rock. The last part of the game I will not spoil as much as others might, but it involves a fairly larger amount of jumping puzzles than the rest of the game, as well as some...interestingly designed levels. It's not exactly bad, but it's definitely a change from the rest of the game that you may not be entirely comfortable with. Which is perhaps what Valve was going for...It's worth mentioning that the multiplayer deathmatch is still around and pretty good, if rather fast-paced. Haven't played much of it, unfortunately. This game also spawned what is perhaps the biggest mod base in video game history. Multiple multiplayer mods for this game became separate commercial releases sanctioned (and usually developed in part by) Valve themselves, such as Counter-Strike and Team Fortress.Overall, I would recommend this as a piece of history, a classic and as a good game even after all these years. Mostly. If you want classic Half-Life with the Source engine, you could try Half-Life Source, or if you want a modernized version you could try Black Mesa. There were also two expansions by Gearbox Software, Opposing Force and Blue Shift, and I'd recommend them if you liked classic Half-Life. Sven Coop is also free on Steam for co-op adventures in the original Half-Life engine, and it even comes with a complementary copy of the HL campaign.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2013
												FPS genre started out with Id Software's Wolfenstein in 1992. That same company later released Doom, and for quite a while most shooters were simply tagged as Doom Clones. Games like Quake, Duke Nukem, Shadow Warrior, Star Wars Dark Forces, Unreal were among them. These games lacked narrative and had a very maze like level design. It's very different from what we have today in our shooters.Then in 1998, came Half Life. Love it or hate it, this game is the blueprint for all the shooters that come out these days. It was among the first shooters to have narrative. To account for the narrative, it had to make the level design more linear. The game is driven by the story, so to say. Level would be build around it, having set pieces here and there.GameplayGames from the Doom era focused on you trying to avoid the incoming projectiles that are shot at you. They focused on mobility. Since they had a very maze like level design. They also would usually have a lot of secret places, where you could get better gear or ammo. Exploration was another thing that was focused on in older fps.Half Life on other hand played differently from earlier FPS games. Accuracy wasn't something that was a thing back then, but with Half Life it was. You had a crosshair and you could not only look at x-axis, but also move your camera up and down (y-axis). All weapons in Half Life would also feature recoil on their guns.You would also face enemies, with guns just like you. They would have cheater like accuracy. You wouldn't be able to dodge their incoming bullets. All you will be able to do is go behind cover.I hope you find all this familiar.That said, Half Life did feature elements from Doom games - mostly when encountering aliens. Headcrabs for example will jump at you. Vortigons would shot a green beam with a few seconds of delay. There are some that that spit corrosive fluid. All of these are dodge-able. The game also has Grunts, which are very big bullet sponges.When encountering normal soldiers on other hand, it will play like today's shooter. Still, there is a fair amount of both in the game.The game still has plenty of secret places with ammo and weapons stashes, so exploration isn't completely off the table.Finally, it features a lot of puzzle solving and platforming, which is a bit unusual for an FPS. I personally found it very frustrating.StoryBack in the days, there was no story in FPS games. And even if there was, it would be delivered via cutscenes. Well, Half Life changed that. Like a said, a linear level design. Along that level, they would have friendly NPCs, with whom you could interact with, and cinematic set pieces. You would do more than just "run and gun".Half Life story may not be unique, but it's about how they deliver it, that makes it so special. No one has ever done that, up till that point. They were the first.Also, it may not look like it, but back then it was amazing. The game didn't even come to PS1 simply because the console couldn't handle the technology involved. Valve used GldSrc, which was based on Quake's engine. It's a groundbreaking game.The only thing i want to complain about is the sounds. It really hurt my ears.This game consists of 18 Chapters and an Epilogue, giving you 2 choices. It's fairly long - about 15 hours.ConclusionI really like Half Life. In fact i like it more than the second game. It has elements from both pre Half Life and post Half Life. I highly recommend it to anyone.Currently, there is a fan made remake called Black Mesa. Better graphics, but the same game. It was developed since 2004 and was released to the public by 2012. That's 8 years of hard work. It's still missing 4 levels, but they plan to add them at some point. Nevertheless, i suggest you to support them.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Game: Half-LifeDeveloper and publisher: Valve SoftwareReleased: 9 November, 1998Genre: First-Person ShooterSetting: 16-17 May, 2003, Black Mesa Research Facility, New Mexico, U.S.A., EarthSpoiler-free plot summary: You play as Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist equipped with a Hazardous Environment Suit and an arsenal of military-grade weapons. After an experiment with an alien crystal goes wrong, creatures from another world begin teleporting into the facility and are attacking all humans on sight. You are tasked by your fellow scientists to travel to the other side of Black Mesa, to its Lambda Complex, in order to stop the alien invasion.Full review: Half-Life is the first game released to be set in the Half-Life/Portal universe. It's one of the few games I keep coming back to play every few months.Half-Life is a typical FPS of the late '90s-early '00s: linear gameplay, a variety of weapons, and puzzle-based objectives.Half-Life can take probably 4 - 6 hours to complete, depending on how fast one usually plays an FPS; everyone has their own style. Personally, I think 4 - 6 hours is the perfect length to play this game; the environments are varied (science labs, abandoned rocket silos, the desert, an alien world), the combat is fair and fluid, the puzzles are mostly easy, and the story, or lack of, doesn't get in the way of the running-and-gunning. Though, eventually, things do get a tad repetitive, but thankfully just barely and the game finishes soon after.Do I recommend buying Half-Life? Yes, especially if you're in the mood for an FPS that can entertain you for the day. For NZD$11.99, I'd wait for a sale for when this game is $5 - $6 before buying it.Half-Life also has a third-party remake in the works called Black Mesa, which is built in the same engine as Half-Life 2. I recommend buying and playing it if you think the original Half-Life hasn't aged that well, or are one of the many people who played Half-Life 2 first and want a more familiar experience with the first Half-Life.

Do not buy this game if the money is tight, save up and buy something featured in the Steam Store.

content:
0, 2014
												Half-Life - One of the most iconic, revolutionary and groundbreaking games of all time, then and now. The original Half-Life and it's expansions are by far some of my all time favourite games, I'd even venture to say that they are in fact my favourite FPS games even to this day, Half-Life defeats any modern FPS game (and Halo games) no competition.I don't know where to begin when it comes to listing my favourite things about this game, there are hardly any faults with it at all. Sure, the graphics may be questionable to some by todays standards, but for it's time they were groundbreaking. A vast selection of weapons, areas, an amazing storyline and puzzles make this one really brilliant single-player experience. The Hazard course by extension is also the most well implemented tutorial I've seen in a game.This is a game that I could play for many more years to come and still enjoy it by setting myself challenges. The only thing that would improve upon Half-Life (and Opposing Force, even Blue Shift) would be to create a list of acheivements just so there is some extra singleplayer playability, but other than that, there is nothing out there in the FPS world that even comes close to matching Half-Life, and I doubt that there ever will be. Valve are amazing story tellers, this is evident in essentially every title that they release with the exception of one or two more silly games and I (like everybody else) eagerly await the upcoming Half-Life titles. It is torture to make somebody wait so long for something so promising. To cut a review short, this game is amazing and it always will be. It is well worth the full retail price and so are it's expansions (even though Blue Shift is extremely short), so pick it up and you won't regret it. Period.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
5, 2015
												Half-Life... That name... No matter if you are a console gamer or just got into gaming and know nothing about the games out there, everyone has heard of or seen somewhere something about Half-Life. This is no wonder, released in 1998 and a true legend in the videogames history for being not only the turning point in Valve's fame and expansion towards creating Steam, developing the mighty Source engine and all other magnificent games they've made over the years, but also for being a thrilling FPS adventure which still fascinates gamers 17 years after the official release.The game manages to completely merge you with the character you are guiding, Gordon Freeman, through the massive Black Mesa venue. You are directly introduced into the action, no overwhelming storytelling, cutscenes or anything like that. By doing this, you get the complete feeling of being where Gordon is, without being rejected from the action as a mere spectator. The story is not at all overloaded with thousdands of plot twists to try to keep the action on. You are given a objective at points and you have to get through loads and loads of unexpected events on the way to your "checkpoint". That makes the gameplay action packed and, most importantly, dynamic.Probably the most impressive thing of the entire game is the incredibly imaginative and complex world in which the game goes on. It is huge (and I think that the word huge is too weak to describe its actual size) and, again, complex as hell. Your main struggle will in all likely be to find the way to the next stage as entrances are well hidden and nearly all of them require you to do something to open it. And yes, you'll need to use your imagination to figure out how to pass through an obstacle or open a locked door. The possible obstacles and their respective ways to overcome them are countless. The game also invites you to explore secret areas in which there may be utilities like weapons, ammo or a warmly welcomed health kit. All in all, the entire game will take around 20 hours to complete entirely.If I described the enemies you'll find through the game, I'd be spoiling the gameplay. Every enemy has his meaning to the storyline, ones more related than others, but generally it's not a bunch of NPCs randomly spawned here and there that you have to kill. As you go past the chapters, the enemies will change. Weapons and armor utilities are also fully connected to the stage you're at and are all completely different. You have three kinds of weapons: fire weapons, experimental weapons (Black Mesa is a research venue) and alien weapons (bit of a spoiler there, so be careful!). The stages through the game will take you to differently ambiented places in which you'll get the respective kind of weapon.Overall, there's not much more to say about this game. I could write the typical pros and cons summary at the end of the review, but it is hard to do. All I can say is that this is a must-have. It's a masterpiece of videogames. No other game, whatever the better graphics and all the new-gen stuff will be as good as this game is unless it pays the same attention to detail, imagination and creativity.10+/10

content:
, 2014
												Mr.Gordan Freeman is just an average 27 year old man (which is somewhat half way through his life, which according to reliable sources is where the name of the game came from) who is late for work one cold Monday morning, as we all are from time to time. Today is once too often though and his employer is non too happy about his lack of time keeping.Upon his late arrival, Mr.Freeman (or as his friends call him, Chungus) finds himself in a bit of a pickle when he finds himself sent to the 'punishment chamber' to think about his inability to get to work on time. Unknown to his employers, Chungus is suffering from a midlife crisis and his recent inprisonment is all that is needed to push this mild mannered telemarketing assistant over the edge.As we see witness the hearthwrenching sight of a man slowly losing his grip on reality, Chungus stands up with his hands to the heavens screaming "What do you mean I can't get to work on time!?!". Picking up his crowbar friend, he breaks out of his prison with only one objective on his mind, to remind his boss why people don't like Mondays.Travel through photorealistic office enviroments as you make your way through endless hoards of enemies to reach your destination at the top of Black Mesa Office Supplies LTD. Evade medical officials as they try to help you with your diminishing grip on reality, plow through the lair of the Human Resourses department, dismember the legions of terrifying un-undead, take control of any piece of office equipment that could arguably be classed as a vehicle.Live through the sadness, the laughter, the action, the romance in this thrilling conclusion to the Half-Live quadrilogy as you fight for the promotion you deserve in this dog eat dog telemarketing adventure through the eyes of a man suffering from schizophrenia, hallucinations, drug withdrawal and a deep clinical depression from the loss of his pet Turtle, 'Simon'."Not many things give me an erection these days but Mr.Freeman has such a supple pair of buttocks and ample breasts that no man could resist his charming personality."* Gavichael Ramsey Jr - RT Magazine *"The game wouldn't close and task manager wouldn't open, so I didn't really have much choice in playing this"* Papa Het - Construction Worker *"Well yea, I guess it technically is a game"* Barry *10/10 Would be late for work again.

												The storyline runs in perfect harmony with the action and acts as a conduit not a stopgap, or a padding device. Each gaming element compliments the next and the entire presentation is nothing short of, well…dare we say it…revolutionary.It constantly presents you with variety, surprises, and new challenges to keep you hooked. It is a tour de force in game design, the definitive single player game in a first person shooter.It combines a balance of tense action, puzzle solving, story, and fun that has yet to be equaled on in the FPS arena.

content:
y 4, 2015
												This is the game that changed FPS games forever.  Before this, the story was a screen of text before a level started.  The storyline was not continued and told solely from the players first person perspective.  The levels were very well designed, the enemies you confronted were smart and varied and required a different approach.  The weapons were varied with secondary abilities.  The sound and music was top notch.  This may not be the prettiest game in the world by today's standard, but the quality of the gameplay from the shooting, to the platforming, to the characters you meet, you will not be disappointed that you got to play the classic game that forever changed the history of gaming and what could be done in a shooter.

content:
, 2016
												I was hesitant to get this or Black Mesa, but i wanted to play the two expansions as well so i went for the classic one. Most of the cool fun parts happen in the first two-thirds of the game, even before you get to Xen, which is just really annoying to play and get through. The last parts before Xen have you doing these mini mazes to turn on reactors and it wears down your patience.The first half is really enjoyable though, watching everything go to sh*t as you unleash the alien hordes on the Black Mesa research facility, and then later having to also fight through the army/marines sent to kill all of you scientists for some reason. If you haven't played it before you may get stuck at some parts as its not made clear where you have to go or what you have to do, "oh i have to jump on this broken ledge and then jump to the other side and crawl into this tiny sewer/crevice, got ya"Graphically it's dated pretty badly, some of the textures may be the worst i've seen in a game,


Textures for days... 
A Screenshot of Half-Life
By: Conker




but then others look ok, so it's a mixed bag. If you haven't played it yet then you should, or play the Black Mesa unoffiicial remake with the updated visuals. That one's not finished though, it doesn't have the last Xen chapter....which just having replayed it may actually be a good thing :/ . Oh yeah and snooping round Gordon Freemans locker, he has a picture of a baby, he has a kid? so in number 2 the kid would be like 8 or 9 at that point?...... i mean he never mentions him/her but then the f*cker's mute, so who knows.


Gordons kid? 
A Screenshot of Half-Life
By: Conker

content:
er 19, 2010
												Maybe Black Mesa... or how Gordon Freeman changed the world - a must-have, if you're not a graphic next-gen purist.During an experiment gone wrong, where you're the one that pushed the crystal into the analyzer, you're the only hope of the survivors to reach the search and rescue team, because of your combinaison. However, you'll have to survive from the attacks of your coworkers transformed in zombies and creatures coming from another world. And unfortunately for you, your only weapon is a crowbar. And you're just a scientist employed by Black Mesa...That's Half-Life for you. A scientist relying on a crowbar first before becoming an expert in weapons. The story is perhaps basic and with some twists but noneless, the universe build around Half-Life has expanded a lot.However, if Half-Life is a FPS, which means weapons to shoot any enemies, that you can carry thanks to your wonderful combinaison, you can find some puzzles throughout the game, mainly because of the need to wander around a destroyed facility.What's fascinating in Half-Life isn't probably the gameplay in itself. I mean, everything seems very basic. But if it wasn't for it, you wouldn't have mods like Counter-Strike around. I don't know why I was fascinated by Half-Life. I mean, it's not like jumping was new or that weapons were innovative... maybe the iconic crowbar has to do something with. Or maybe it's just that a plot, perhaps basic but very effective, the mysterious G-Man following you around and disappearing easily or that the fact it's someone that wasn't trained to become the hero of the world... or maybe the ending. I don't know but I just know that when I played it, I was fascinated.I was fascinated by the fact that you can find survivors around that can help you, guards or scientists. Or the fact that some of them meet a tragic fate under your eyes. I was fascinated by the change of the objectives: from reaching the surface, you're now the only hope to end an invasion and the wiping of any survivor by the soldiers.I don't remember any problem with the gameplay apart the treacherous ladders. Climbing them isn't hard. However, when you needed to step out of them OR going down, it was a challenge. And the famous jumping with the crates where you were sliding...Half-Life has the graphics from 1998 and it was very good ones. Even now, I could still enjoy them. I don't say that it's detailed. But you can see some interesting details. And Xen, the other world, despite being a challenge, is very beautiful.Besides, the soundtrack is also great. It's only heard during some important moments. But the music is powerful.Half-Life is a classic to have. Gordon Freeman is a character that you can't forget.

content:
2015
												Half Life is a First Person Shooter that takes place in a hidden laboratory that experiments with teleportation. As you can guess things quickly go wrong and our protagonist Gordon Freeman must fight to survive. Gordon is an engineer but he is proficient with firearms and has no qualms about killing. He is a generic mute character with no personality and very little back-story. As is pretty much everyone you meet throughout this adventure. There are only three character models of scientists and one character model of the security guard rehashed throughout the game. It quickly makes you stop caring if they survive an encounter since you will surely meet the same exact guy again. I know it is from 1998 but it would have been better to make those three scientist models count and have actual characters in the game instead of meeting an endless clone of scientists throughout. The story is told during gameplay and there are no cutscenes which is nice. If you don't care about story you can just as easily whack the character talking instead of listening to them. There is no consequence for killing allies but sometimes they do lead to some extra loot or simply help you fight off aliens. It feels like a grand adventure since all the missions are seamless and connect together perfectly. Most of the areas early on are bland and gray but it is impressive how much variety there is in the actual objectives to get through them. It is never as simple as running and gunning, if something can go wrong it always does for poor Gordon.Which leads to my main problem with the game. The amount of platforming is kind of ridiculous and it  feels pretty awkward. They also demand too much precision as well as that annoying need to crouch jump to reach just a tiny bit higher so you can jump over certain objects. Another similar problem is that ladders are extremely unreliable and you never know if Gordon will hold on to it causing you to have to try over and over again. Luckily missing it is very rarely fatal although trying to go down one can be fatal as Gordon decides he has no need for ladders and that he can land a 30 ft fall. Quick saving is a godsend and makes these situations much more tolerable. The puzzles are never too complicated though the game can be inconsistent at times such as certain identical objects are not destructible but suddenly one is. Or just plain odd like them expecting you to figure out you can change tracks by shooting a sign during the railcart level.Actual gameplay fairs a lot better. You start off with a crowbar and quickly get a pistol which I used throughout the whole game since it has decent damage and is very accurate.  Most of the weapons are pretty standard like an assault rifle, shotgun and revolver but there are some pretty unique weapons late game. Some do share certain types of ammo like the assault rifle and the pistol. The assault rifle and shotgun are pretty inaccurate which makes sense considering Gordon is an engineer.  Gordon's main source of survival is some kind of special suit that takes the impact out of most damage and allows navigation through toxic hazards. For a while at least, Gordon does not wear a helmet for some reason and the toxicity will kill him eventually. The suit works pretty much the same as armor from any other FPS of the time and can be recharged by finding small glowing vials or through a wall mounted H.E.V center. The same goes for health, both first aid kits laying around and wall mounted health centers will heal you.Enemies in this game each have their own unique attack patterns and have pretty good AI. Most of the time humans will be your greatest foe since bullets are way too fast to dodge in this and they pull off impressive maneuvers at times such as when you chase them they drop a grenade behind them allowing them to regroup. The security guards yo can have follow you around are completely useless on the other hand. Most of the times they don't react until they get struck first and are only useful to distract the enemies. The game does steadily introduce new powerful enemies but you will be fighting mostly the same group of enemies from beginning to end. Aliens do look very weird and are not simply just humanoid enemies. Some enemies have weird death animations that play whenever they are dying so make sure to recognize them and not waste any ammo even though they are still moving.Overall Half Life is a pretty good game but don't let all the praise make you expect something amazing. There is no gripping story here nor is there even any characters aside from one mysterious man. Platforming in a FPS very rarely works and it sure as heck doesn't here. Still it is a solid title when it is not trying to be an Adventure game instead of a FPS. Half Life continue to be supported after all these years so it features modern controls and modern resolutions which is always nice. The physics like boxes floating on water and some puzzles solved by it are pretty fun to watch and neat. This is definitely a thinking mans shooter, you will be fighting your surroundings as much as shooting guns. If you can stomach all the forced platforming and want more in your FPS than shooting hordes of bad guys this is the game for you.

content:
1, 2016
												First I have to say I have played this game so many times I have lost count, why write a review of it after first playing it in 1998? well after reading daft click bait negative reviews about the game, by small few with attention issues. Ever since stepping off that train and being told have a very safe and productive day, my gaming life has never been the same since.The legacy this game has produced can never be underestimated, from the first modded map I ever played on in TFC 1.5 to counterstrike, tf2, death match, and so much more in between. Do I really need to say anything about the contents of this game? Immersive story, enigmatic lead character, the infamous crow bar,. The fact that the story was driven along so well without the need for cut scenes. Its just a magnificent game that even today is fun to run through and explore.If you don't own the game then buy it, if you have never played the game before then I am envious as I remember the first time playing it and being blown away, its a game that every self respecting PC gamer should own and play. Forget the negative minority of click baiter's just buy it and enjoy.

content:
r 7, 2015
												A 5/5 star classic, Half Life, a FPS FULL of action and suspense all about surviving an alien apocolapse and putting an end to it by going into space and confronting the boss responsible, if you haven't played HL1 yet this one is UNMISSABLE, go ahead and get a copy if you've never played it "They're waiting for you Gordon, in the test chamber."Onto more detail, was released in 1998 shortly before the PS2 era, from the talking suit you wear that protects you and warns you of danger, killing aliens, escorting fellow scientists and working together with security guards, you'd think your chances of survival are good? Well you're in for a surprise when you meet the military grunts, lets just say although they help exterminate the alien races they're not trying to get you or your co-workers and friends out alive. There's even a few areas in the game where stealth will give you an advantage weather it's surprising the unsuspecting with satchel charges or sneaking passed a blind and unkillable monster, being trapped in a shark cage fighting off an ichthyosaur (Terrifying creature) with a crossbow before you end up drowning and even killing the dreaded gargantua who's completely bullet-proof and 5 times your height.The "cutscenes" were a completely new thing in this game because they give you the freedom to walk around and do what you like as your co-workers are giving you information about the situation, if you're bored and want some fun you could try stirring up some trouble with them with some gunfire. This is definately a game worth playing if you're into surviving disasters and constant action, all I can say if you decide to go ahead and play it is "Wisely done Mr Freeman!"

												A great classic and yet another must for all FPS lovers!This game pretty much pioneered with many things later found in a lot of FPS: "mute" protagonist, lots of weapons (classic and futuristic/alien), big variety of enemies/bosses and levels (even for today's standards), a bit of mystery/horror and an engaging story, left open for a sequel.After all those years and despite having been outdated by many modern games, it still holds up well today, you can see what made it great at the time!The game's "man with a gun" (or crowbar), the scientist Gordon Freeman, also became quite an iconic protagonist, boosting the belief that "nerds can be cool too"!Some influences seem to have been taken from Wolfenstein 3D/Original Doom, though in their turn the latter games's sequels seem to have taken influences from Half-Life, showing how important all those games were for the FPS genre.The whole "protagonist in a robotic suit, fighting a variety of aliens and marines" plot, makes me think that Halo probably also got some influences from here.The addition of G-man as an antagonist, who watches your progress as you march further and further in the game and only those who pay attention will notice, was also great!Finally, if I had to name just a minor flaw that would be that I didn't find the music addictive enough, it seemed almost non-existent to me (Return to Castle Wolfenstein for example had a great soundtrack and totally immersed you in the game), but don't let this small factor drive you away from this gem of a game, you can't be considered a true FPS fan until you have played this!

1, 2016
												First I have to say I have played this game so many times I have lost count, why write a review of it after first playing it in 1998? well after reading daft click bait negative reviews about the game, by small few with attention issues. Ever since stepping off that train and being told have a very safe and productive day, my gaming life has never been the same since.The legacy this game has produced can never be underestimated, from the first modded map I ever played on in TFC 1.5 to counterstrike, tf2, death match, and so much more in between. Do I really need to say anything about the contents of this game? Immersive story, enigmatic lead character, the infamous crow bar,. The fact that the story was driven along so well without the need for cut scenes. Its just a magnificent game that even today is fun to run through and explore.If you don't own the game then buy it, if you have never played the game before then I am envious as I remember the first time playing it and being blown away, its a game that every self respecting PC gamer should own and play. Forget the negative minority of click baiter's just buy it and enjoy.

content:
8, 2014
In Half-Life you play as Gordon Freeman, one of the Black Mesa Research Facility's scientists. One of the experiments in the facility went horribly wrong, causing to open a rift between your dimension and an alien dimension, and you were unfortunate enough to be, in fact, the one that technically accidentaly caused it.    Now, stuck in the middle of this mess, your goal is to get out of the alien-infested facility, however, it may not be as simple as it at first seems, and aliens might not be the only enemies you will encounter on your way. The gameplay in this game is great and challenging. You can't run out guns blazing into enemies' faces here. You have to stay in cover, watch out for enemies trying to flank you and... well... shoot at them, of course. The soundtrack, while definetly more of the memorable ones, is unfortunately nothing special Except of Nuclear Mission Jam, it makes you cream your pants. However, music in this game doesn't play too often anyway, most of the time the only sounds you hear are footsteps and gunfire, so it does give this little special feeling when you do hear music. Graphics, while for today standards are bad, back when this game was released were good. Nothing really sensational, but they did hold up back then.   Game DEFINETLY worth buying. So now stop reading all those reviews, get your steam loaded with some $cash money$, buy this game and play it for Christ's sake.

content:
y 8, 2015
												If you're a gamer and have never heard the name Half-Life, I'm sorry to say that you're either overly sheltered, willfully ignorant or just too young. For those of us who enjoy First-Person Shooter [FPS] games, Half-Life was just as influential to the genre as Doom or Quake (for those of you who have never heard of these titles, Wikipedia is your friend). Classics such as Halo: Combat Evolved and newer titles such as Bioshock: Infinite have been influenced by this game, and older games such as Counter-Strike were mods of Half-Life. In short, the entire FPS genre has been creatively influenced by the atmosphere and style of Half-Life.                          - FYI: Final Score is at the end -- The Look - Half-Life was released by Valve (the parent company of Steam) in 1998 for the PC. As such, the graphics are abysmal by modern standards. If you are a nostalgic gamer such as myself, though, the low graphics can be humorous and even add to the charm of the game at times. There are numerous texture packs available if you cannot handle such old graphics.- The Story (Mild Spoiler Alert) - You're a government agent/scientist who gets involved with some experiments on unknown substances. Through testing these substances, you somehow open a portal and unleash an alien horde into the testing facility. You must then find and fight your way out of the facility. Pretty simple and straightforward-sounding. Half-Life was the first-ever game to tell its story completely through scripted sequences (events triggered by certain programmable requirements) and as such has no cutscenes. This is a very nice element to the game as you retain control of your character throughout the entire game.- The Sounds - For some reason, Valve decided they needed to make everything sound like it was coming from the inside of an echo chamber. There is a lot of reverb on just about every noise if you are not completely outdoors. Again, this is an element where modern technology has progressed as to make this appear foolish and unappealing. Give it some time before you make any judgments, though. The effect enhances the scariness of some situations, in my opinion. If you ever play any of the other Valve games (Portal, Team Fortress 2, Portal 2, etc.), you will discover that a LOT of sounds and music in those games originated from Half-Life.- The Movement - You run. You run a lot. You run really fast. You have the option to walk and the option to sneak, but 98% of the time you will be running. Sometimes, especially for unfamiliar novices to the game, the speed is too much and you end up running into an alien patrol before you realize that you just passed through that hallway. You will eventually get used to it, though. Half-Life was one of the first games (if not the first; I'm not sure) to implement the "jump-crouch" concept. If you jump and hold the crouch button, you can actually jump onto higher platforms. Instead of lowering your body, jump-crouching raises your legs and feet, giving you more clearance to vault onto objects.- The Combat - If an enemy sees you, they will throw a grenade. Expect to be spammed if you are spotted. Half-Life is a quick-save/quick-load supportive game; you can choose to disregard this if you want a "purist" experience. Enemies in this game are rather easy to defeat in the beginning and get harder as the game progresses, but each new type presents its own unique traits that make it hard to kill. The weapon switching system is confusing to a modern gamer at first; it requires you to scroll (or press hot-key) and then left-click to actually arm that weapon. The left shift button, by default, switches instantaneously back to the previous weapon used, allowing for a much faster switch. Weapons and ammo are decently plentiful if you are conservative enough.- The Mods and The Legacy - Half-Life is the number one most modded game of all time. There are more mods available for this game than any other, followed by Morrowind and Quake. The mods have spawned entire new game series, as in the case of Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Half-Life also holds the trophy for another gaming phenomenon: most-played for speedruns. If you are unfamiliar with a speedrun, the gist is that you attempt to start and finish the game as fast as possible.- The Downsides - Half-Life is an ancient piece of software by today's standards. With the advent of 2015, this game is now 17 years old (nearly old enough to purchase cigarettes!). Its age shows in many things. Several furniture items are completely cubic or square and have no roundness. Cockroaches are diamond-shaped. There are only three different models used for the human enemies and three for the friendly scientists. Each alien type has only one model/skin. The NPCs and enemies can get very repetitive at times, as such. Other than this, there aren't very many bad points to Half-Life. Its continued success and popularity speak for its quality and innovation.- The Conclusion - Half-Life is a classic in many gamers' opinions. I am of the same mindset. I completely recommend this game, despite its age and shortcomings, as a fun experience that will provide a decent challenge.Final Score: 10/10

content:
13, 2013
												Half-Life 1 is a really nice game.It got released in 1998 and so it looks really old but it can be a lot of fun. Half-Life is a classic.You are a scientist called Gordon Freeman. One day you are involved in a critical test which goes terribly wrong and opens portals to the boarderland Xen. From that moment on, aliens invade earth and you find yourself in chaos and try to get out alive.The singleplayer was revolutionary at the time because it has a continious story without cutscenes. I also like that there are a lot of enemy-types. The weapons are all really balanced (except gluongun) and fun to use. The story develops as you proceed in the game. It gets more and more mysterious and suspense.In Half-Life you are mostly on your own and travel through many interessting environments. Sometimes the maps can be a bit confusing but in the end you will have a nice final and it feels great to finish the game.In my opinion Half-Life's multiplayer is very very good. I played it a very long time and it has a great learning-curve. In Half-Life you have very dynamic gameplay with fast movement, air-control, excessive wallbanging and spawnkilling. It can be a really great feel to dominate and control the whole map. In Half-Life you can play many styles.. aggressive like a berserker but also slow and silent. It's possible to break the enemies advantage by clever ambushing and by hitting well aimed headshots. Since there are many different weapons you can always find different ways to deal with your enemy. Each weapon is very different and good in special situations. Also the maps are all very different to each other. Each map has it's own great design and unique gameplay.Conclusion:I recommend you to try Half-Life on LAN with friends, because it's a lot of fun to play against enemies of equal skill. Since it has a great learning-curve you have to get into the game a bit.If you want to play online I recommend you to edit your config-file so you can have a field of view of 110 degrees and direct weapon-bindings. On most servers (Adrenaline Gamer Mod) you can use bunnyhop. Since they patched Half-Life you are no longer able to code bunnyhop-scripts in your config. So if you want a working bhop you have to use a macro programm like autohotkey or maybe your keyboard-driver. The other easier way to use bhop is to disable automatic updates and patch back half-life to an older version (still works online).Half-Life has a lot of mods and there is a lot of custom content (player and weapon-models, maps, effects and hud-elements). I recommend you to install good visible custom crosshairs and use simple explosion sprites.Regarding mods I can recommend you Adrenaline Gamer, Sven-Coop 3.0 (because it has the original Half-Life weapons and basicly is a coop mod for Half-Life), The Specialists (a Matrix-styled mod) and Frontline Force.There are also a lot great singleplayer mods. I can recommend you Half-Life Invasion, Escape from the Darkness, Paranoia, Todesangst, ETC 1 and 2, Sweet Half-Life and a lot more.Seriously there are a lot good mods out there..All in all for me this game is a must have. So if you don't mind the old graphics and take some time to understand the game.. I think you will like it!

content:
8, 2014
												That moment when barnacle pulled me out of water after fight with ichtyosaur in „Forget about Freeman!” chapter is – as for now – the closest moment in my almost-20-year life for getting a heart attack. I put into that creature whole magazine of Glock (even though I knew it dies after 4 hits), went few metres away and thought that I really can't play this game anymore. I had to turn it off. That „anymore” lasted about 4 days, then I sat again to Half-Life. Unfortunately, I didn't know how to pass teleport part in Lambda Core, scientist kept getting killed… Anyway, it was when I didn't know anything about HL. I knew only that it is the best game I've ever played. A couple of years later I made a Steam Account, bought HL Complete Pack, L4D2, L4D1 (which overpassed HL in best game ever played) and other games, but still Half-Life has reserved place on my HDD. Even if I'm not playing it now anyway, it deserves it. Great story, astonishing gameplay, thrilling, but not too scary overview.In nutshell: Not playing HL1 will be your biggest mistake as FPS player.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2014
												É um ótimo FPS com uma ambientação e uma história bem interessantes. Você está no controle de Gordon Freeman, um físico que trabalha na Black Mesa Research Facility, onde são feitos diversos tipos de pesquisas. Freeman participa de um experimento que dá errado, criando um efeito cascata que ocasiona a invasão de aliens no local. Assim, ele precisa entender como reverter o incidente. O jogo tem diversos tipos de armas e de inimigos que, sem querer dar muito spoiler, não se limitam a extra-terrestres. A ação é o foco, mas não quer dizer que você não terá que parar e pensar um pouco em alguns momentos para resolver situações pontuais a fim de poder progredir. Uma facilidade que o jogo tem é poder salvá-lo a qualquer momento. Hoje em dia os gráficos não são tão atrativos, mas para a época de lançamento com certeza surpreenderam. A trilha sonora é quase inexistente, servindo para marcar apenas alguns momentos. Há mais de um final possível e um deles vai desenvolver os eventos em Half-Life 2. Então, se você tem interesse em shooters clássicos, não deixe de conferir Half-Life e de entender os detalhes de sua trama. E lembrando que existem mais duas histórias que se passam nas mesmas ocasiões, com personagens diferentes, em Half-Life Opposing Force e Half-Life Blue Shift.

content:
er 7, 2014
												Half-Life is my old love so I found this review kind of hard to put together, since I had to put aside my nostalgia and deliberate precisely on what makes Half-Life an excellent game, but here goes my best.Half-Life is seemingly a classic FPS however back when It was released it was anything BUT, Half-Life was a frigging revolutionary game that defied FPS standards while still preserving what makes FPS fun and good. And Half-Life IS fun, Its got a wide and diverse range of weapons and enemies (as well as some cool bosses) and some brilliant AI that still impresses me today.But what really makes Half-Life a really stand out game is what it does that is different. Rather then going the way of a metal gear solid game valve opted for a really interesting minimal storytelling approach in which everything is witnessed through the gameplay, there are no cutscenes of any kind. The less is more approach works and instead of long pieces of poorly written dialogue the game lets you observe first hand the chaos and destruction in the aftermath of the Black Mesa Incident. It works and the atmosphere feels like the aftermath of some kind of horrible and ongoing disaster like a huricane or a Nuclear blast In which you must fight for your life throughout the game to escape.Rather than explain everything to you Half-Life will show you a lot of things or occasionaly say things that may confuse you. This is because you are just one man and its impossible for you to comprehend the big picture, you are small and insignificant in this grand scheme going on and while you get vague hints throughout the game as to this bigger picture the game leaves you guessing which gives the game a large sense of a forboding and sinister mystery .This game is built on atmosphere and while the graphics have aged a lot, it is still a breath taking experiance to witness the disaster and destruction of Black Mesa. The sounds and music are top notch and aid with this of course.If you are one of the few people who has not played Half-Life yet I really suggest that you get around to it, you wont just have fun but I think It will probably influence your opinion on how Video Game stories and atmosphere should be handled in relation to gameplay.

												I finally got the chance to buy & play this amazing game in the steam exploration sale so I'll try my best to explain this game in my point of view.Oh boy where to start well for starters this game is one of the main reasons Valve is highly respected & over 4 million gamers are still waiting for Half Life 3 including me, Gordon Freeman is a badass scientist that can fight off the military & a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of aliens, lots of weapons to choose from, the atmosphere is pretty spot on with the suspense of fighting off soldiers or just overall creepiness in Xen (the alien world), I could tell the game has had a lot of love because the game works fine on any PC & there's so many great things I can say about this game but I don't want to make an entire list of everything. G-man a.k.a Government Man (The slang is right here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G-Man_%28slang%29 if you don't know what it means) interests me because of his mysterious behaviour & everyone still wants to know if he fights for good or evil but some things in life can't be answered but I don't know if we could all handle the truth.... if you really want more questions added I would suggest this video it gives out some good theories on G-Man & many others you can watch on youtube.

The game has few minor bugs but the game still holds out as one of the grandfathers of the FPS genre & still popular for a 16 year old game so my final verdict is to get this game. Don't forget keep some head crabs as souvenirs on your grand adventures in Black Mesa, Freeman's grandkids might want it for their school project or for bragging rights on how cool their grandpa was back in his scientific glory. content:
y 6, 2014
												Half-Life! A Sci-Fi First Person Shooter game devloped by the Almighty Valve under His Excellency, The Most Honourable Gabe Logan Newell. Half-Life is what made Valve what it is today, their very first product that went on to be praised by all. Its gameplay defined and influenced many FPS games that came to ensue.In Half-Life, players assume the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a theoretical scientist who must fight his way out of a secret research installation known as the "Black Mesa Research Facility" in which experiments into teleportation technology turns deadly!A game that is one of the greatest and not to mention winning over 50 GOTYs and just being an amazing game in general.Good:-Crowbar!-Simple solid story-Very fun game!-Immersive and interactive environment-This is where the iconic FPS game Counter Strike originated.-Has a Guiness World Record XD-Half-Life's design helped revolutionise First Person Shooters-One of the scientists looks like Albert Einstein Bad:-Gameplay mechanics are accelerated and very sensitiveHighly inspired, Half-Life went above and beyond.  10 Foxes out of 10 Foxes. GG

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2016
												This is the FPS. Half-Life MADE the FPS type of game. For the 90s, it was very different. You werem't shot into a base on Mars, fighting every demon under the sun. You were a normal scientist who was at the wrong place at the wrong time. You, Gordon Freeman, must fight your way through a alien-infested under ground base called Black Mesa. Sounds boring, well its not. The wide range of aliens to fight and their amazing A.I will scare you!As for the FPS portion, its also great. You see everything from the eyes of Gordon Freeman. There is a reason you can take a lot of damage and why there is a HUD, your Hazardous Enviroment Vest (H.E.V) or better known as the H.E.V suit, protects you from a wide range of dangers. To freezing cold chambers to electricity-shooting aliens, it protects you. Giving a reason why you can take so much.The weapons are great! They're placed very well. You find the shotgun in a little base wich makes sence, you find the glock next to the dead body of a guard, etc... Also the ammo changes too! Depending on wich part of the base you are, the will be more or less of a ammo type, forcing you to use all your weapons in order to survive.As for the story, it makes so real sence...but its great. A huge amount of mass builds up, creating a portal between Earth and the border world, ZEN were aliens have been hiding from the Combine (as seen in Half-Life 2). They flee to Earth hence why the base is over run with aliens. The militery come to kill the aliens...and the survivors. Its a goverment cover-up and you're Black Mesa's best hope of cleaning the base of all aliens and soldiers.Over all: Buy it, you won't regret it...

content:
y 3, 2016
												I was sitting inside a small monorail carriage. The underground transit system was huge. What was this place? A friendly female voice welcomed me. "Good Morning, and welcome to the Black Mesa Transit system. This automated train is provided for the security and convenience of the Black Mesa research facility personnel. The time is 8:47 a.m., current topside temperature is 93 degrees with an estimated high of 105. The Black Mesa compound is maintained at a pleasant 68 degrees at all times. This train is inbound from level three dormitories to sector C test labs and control facilities. If your intended destination is a high security area beyond sector C, you will need to return to the central transit hub in sector G and board a high security train. If you have not yet submitted your identity to a retinal client system, you must report to Black Mesa personnel for processing before you will be permitted to enter the high security branch of the transit system. Due to the high toxicity of the materials routinely handled in the Black Mesa Compound, no smoking, eating, or drinking is permitted inside the transit system. Please keep your limbs in the train at all times. Do not attempt to open the doors until the train has come to a complete stop at the station platform. In the event of an emergency, passengers are to remain seated and await further instructions. If it is necessary to leave the train, disabled personnel should be evacuated first. Please, stay away from electrified rails and proceed to an emergency station until assistance arrives. A reminder that the Black Mesa hazard course decathlon will commence this evening at 19:00 hours, in the level 3 facility. The semi-finals will later be announced in the secure access train. Remember, more lives than your own may depend on your fitness. Do you have a friend or relative who would make a valuable addition to the Black Mesa team? Immediate openings are available in the areas of: materials handling, and low clearance security. Please contact Black mesa personnel if you would like to sponsor someone. If you have any education in the areas of theoretical physics, unusual technology, or other high-end disciplines, contacts the Black Mesa facility. A reminder to all personnel: Regular radiation and biohazard screenings are a requirement of continued employment in the Black Mesa Research Facility. Missing a scheduled analysis or check-up is grounds for immediate termination. If you feel you have been exposed to radioactive or other materials, contact your head of duties and contact your radiation safety officer immediately. Work safe, work smart, your future depends on it. Now arriving at sector C test labs and control facilities. Please stand back from the automated door, and wait for the security officer to confirm your identity. Before exiting the train, be sure to check you area for personal belongings. Thank you, and have a very safe and productive day."  Finally, the ride came to a halt.The guard opened the door and I entered the administration centre. "Morning, Mr. Freeman. Looks like you’re running late. "And so it began.One of the best games ever made, a genre defining classic. An intriguing story/universe, the start of something 'special'."With my brains and your brawn we'll make an excellent team."I want to go back. Please Valve, let me go back to Black Mesa.10/10

content:
3, 2015
												There is not much to say about this old game that hasn't been said really. Many people have played Half-Life 2 and the episodes, but sometimes there are those few who haven't really tried out the original Half-Life, along with it's expansions Blue Shift and Opposing Force. I also never played Half-Life, so I decided to try it out. Many mechanics are simialr to its sequel with many of the same guns, along with some other ones unique to this game. This game is an amazing experience from the begining to the end, despite the not as strong end levels, but still, it's a great shooter with great mechanics and gunplay, along with great level desgin not seen as much now in today's corridor shooters. The story is presented through the eyes of the silent Gordon Freeman the entire time, and despite the games old graphics, still makes the game incredibly immersive, even more so than many games today on the market. The expansions are also worth your time and are neccessary to purchase, and you can get a discount by buying the Half Life 1 Anthology. The only reason you would not play this is the simplistic graphics, but with people playing games like Minecraft, along with the greatness of this historic masterpiece, this is a must buy, and you should definitely be played BEFORE PLAYING HALF-LIFE 2 AND THE EPISODES. Anyway, I was just bored and had some time on my hands. So just remember, NEVER be late for work.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Short version: good, but probably not as good as you've heard. Still get itLong version: It's a well-made game, and it's very clever in terms of the gameplay (i.e. boss fights are a bit more complicated than in most games, you have to think around the location of the fight, not the "health" of the boss persay). The graphics are as good as they need to be, they may seem a bit dated, but they're still good. Really, my only problem with this game is that it's very gimmicky and way overhyped (I could say the same about half-life 2). Is it a great shooter? yes. One of the best of it's era? Sure. The best shooter ever? God no! I personally enjoyed games like doom and Bioshock more, because they don't try to skirt around the fun of shooting things with how "groundbreaking" they are get in the way of their fun. General pros and Cons:Pros:+ It's a good shooter+ well-done setpieces that involve the player+ Great worldbuilding+ Good piece of gaming history+ Varied and interesting gamplayCons:- Slow paced- Unfair at times- Breeds a fanbase prone to overhyping itWorth the purchase on sale or bundled with the expansions

content:
7, 2016
												So what is Half-Life? Well it's got a simple story: You work in an underground research facility and some stuff goes wrong, unleashing aliens into the facility. You try and fight your way out to the surface but the military comes in with grunts and ninjas forcing you back undeground. There a team of scientists transports you to the alien homeworld where you kill an oversized fetus. This weird guy with a briefcase turns up and offers you a job. You accept and the game ends on a cliffhanger.Half-Life's gameplay is set up in a way that there are no cutscenes. You are in control of Gordon Freeman from beginning to end. It's this gameplay feature that makes this game special, makes it stand out from the crowd as a revolutuionary rollercoaster of epicness. It's not all combat though, sometimes you'll have to navigate puzzles and while that may turn off some players, they're not that bad. Most of the time there will be enemies to keeps you on your toes so be careful!This is my favourite game of all time, been playing it since I was a kid. I'd definetley recommend it to fans of FIrst-Person Shooters.10/10

You were a normal scientist who was at the wrong place at the wrong time. You, Gordon Freeman, must fight your way through a alien-infested under ground base called Black Mesa. Sounds boring, well its not. The wide range of aliens to fight and their amazing A.I will scare you!As for the FPS portion, its also great. You see everything from the eyes of Gordon Freeman. There is a reason you can take a lot of damage and why there is a HUD, your Hazardous Enviroment Vest (H.E.V) or better known as the H.E.V suit, protects you from a wide range of dangers. To freezing cold chambers to electricity-shooting aliens, it protects you. Giving a reason why you can take so much.The weapons are great! They're placed very well. You find the shotgun in a little base wich makes sence, you find the glock next to the dead body of a guard, etc... Also the ammo changes too! Depending on wich part of the base you are, the will be more or less of a ammo type, forcing you to use all your weapons in order to survive.As for the story, it makes so real sence...but its great. A huge amount of mass builds up, creating a portal between Earth and the border world, ZEN were aliens have been hiding from the Combine (as seen in Half-Life 2). They flee to Earth hence why the base is over run with aliens. The militery come to kill the aliens...and the survivors. Its a goverment cover-up and you're Black Mesa's best hope of cleaning the base of all aliens and soldiers.Over all: Buy it, you won't regret it...

er 4, 2015
												Half-Life is an amazing FPS experience released almost 20 years ago and that still hold strong today. The graphics will look dated to some, and the sound can be unbearable to others, but the story and the way the environment is layed out makes you realize how much work went into this (It must have been amazing to play this in 1998).The game is the classic shooter experience where you grind through waves of enemies, sometimes fighting a boss or one of the huge mobs that appear from time to time. The game is very hard, even at the lower difficulties (much harder than HL2) and is a good challenge for fans of old-school FPS classics such as Doom and Quake.I recommend any game from the Half-Life series because of the effort that went into making these games. If you really can't stand the graphics and sound, you can always check out Black Mesa, a remake of HL1 (it isn't completely done yet iirc).

content:
3, 2016
												One of my All time favorite games. It had everything i desire from a game in 1998. It is impressive. For today's standards, it has aged graphics, but still plays extremely well, and is really entertaining. Story is told mostly via dialogue from other characters, as the main character is mute, well at least in the game(s). I doubt he is really mute if he got a job like that.You shoot your way through aliens, and soldiers which try to kill everything inside the Black Mesa Facility. Levels are diverse, game is long enough for single player campaign. I love it.Apart from SP, game has multiplayer modes, which probably isn't that much populated. To compensate that, there are tons of mods for HL1. New gamemodes for MP, new maps, whole new single player games. Just google some of the best mods, and you have so many that you won't know which to play. Classic, you should play this if you have not already. If you have, play it again!If you are turned off by the looks of the game( Which I don't think should be a problem, it's older game)Look up Black Mesa on steam. It's HL2 Mod, which remade HL1 into HL2's engine, which better visuals and other tweaks.  Black Mesa is still missing the games ending at the moment( Early 2016), but otherwise it's solid example of good remaster.

content:
er 3, 2014
												I shall direct this review for the people that haven't played or heard of this game-Yes, this is that one.  The game that all others were measured against for a long, long time.In a world where FPS games compelled you to shoot anything that moved in fantastical arenas with weapons that floated and rotated in the air, Half-Life came along and quietly stated....."I want to tell a story"It doesn't thrust you into the shoes of a hardcore soldier or special forces operative, you start your day with a leisurely train ride.  As a scientist.  Going to work.  Just like any other day...The level design was phenominal and vaired.  The combat was robust and fun.  I'll stop there.The bottom line is...this game costs almost nothing and will run on almost anything out there today.  Your excuses are limited to why you wouldn't try your hand at this classic.  Modern gamers might have to put on rose covered glasses and step back a few years to fully appreciate it when it was cutting edge and new...but names like Blast Pit, Surface Tension, and Xen still mentioned by some with warm feelings and happy memories even to this day.  And if you can't stomach the GoldSource engine...download Black Mesa.This is one that I wish I could experience again for the first time.

ry 8, 2015
												First off if your tired of FPS that are like COD, Battlefield, etc than Half-Life is the game for youPros:-Very original story (It is told through dialogue, and your always in the First-Person).-Excellent gameplay (HL's gameplay is a mixture of stealth at some sequences and all out guns blazing in others)-All elements to me are original-Cool protagonist-Pretty awesome weapons-Challenging enemies in well designed mapsCons:-Some minor glitches (like getting stuck on a wall which can be fixed by shooting your weapon) (This was all on my version, not sure if it will appear in yours)-Clunky platforming sections (There will be some parts of the game where platforming is required, and even if it looks like you can make the jump, you slip sometimes of the ledge).-No Half-Life 3Overall 9/10Half-Life is an excellent game, but some minor glitches and the platforming sections frustrated me a little.Half-Life is a masterpiece and not only do a recommend Half-Life 1, but buy Half-Life 1 Anthology and The Orange Box for Gordon Freeman's journey in fullNow stay tuned for my review of Half-Life: Opposing Force...

content:
r 1, 2015
												From playing and completing this game I can tell how this was a masterpiece in 1998. However, I'm reviewing this for the people like me who never played this game when they were younger. So I want to answer the question. Is this game still worth a buy and a play in 2015? So, a problem I seemed to have from the outset is that this game just assumes you know things, or you know the games concepts and mechanics already. There is never a tutorial of any type and in fact I got stuck for a solid 10 minutes at the very start of the game because I simply didn't know you could press "e" on people to make them follow you. Like, really? The game never told me I could do that. That is just one example of the game just assuming you know how to play.Secondly, if you really look at this game. In essence, it is a very repetitive shooter. You pretty much do the same thing throughout the whole game from the first hour to the tenth hour. It didn't make me bored, but I can imagine it might make some people very bored.Let me just add, THIS GAME IS HARD. Like, really really hard. I played on normal, and, oh my god. Just expect to die a lot. Over and over again to the same section, and throughout many sections in the entire game. It was at some points frustratingly difficult as I would find myself saving progress every 30 seconds at some points just because this try I did a little better and didn't lose too much health.HOWEVER, that is the gem in this game. Because it was so difficult. It made me so happy to finally get past sections and eventually complete the game. I actually felt a sense of achievement beating this. Like a "I beat half life!!!" That is what gaming should be all about and it's a shame most AAA games lack that these days.So, although this game has aged a lot, and elements are very outdated and in some circumstances, quite frankly, pretty awful. That doesn't take away from this game. This is a good game. I believe this game was enjoyable enough to still be worth a buy and play even in 2015.

content:
12, 2014
												Half-Life - a word used for stating the time it takes for a nuclear substance to reach half its original amount, but also - a great game!Released for Windows computers originally in November 19th, 1998, it came to redefine the era of modern first-person shooters. With a simple change in concept compared to other big games of the time, namely the fact that you never leave the players field of vision, the focus was always on the player, even during special events in the storyline. And the story - what a story it was and still is!In the game, you play as Gordon Freeman, an M.I.T graduate in Theoretical Physics, who is called to the Black Mesa Complex as a Research Associate for a large-scale experiment involving alien artifacts. Already from the get-go, you may pass your time by speaking to, or just listen to the conversations between scientists and security guards. You may interact with doors, buttons, microwaves, soda machines - I mean, what more can anyone ask for, right? I am not going to spoil the story for anyone interested in playing the game themselves (go play it already, if you haven't!), but I can say that the ability to interact with the surrounding world is something that the player learns to appreciate throughout the game. Because of this ability, there are often several ways to complete a certain task (moving boxes, blowing things up, pressing a switch so that you don't get caught by an electrified wire etc.). This is something that  works very well with the game's overall story and design.As the game progresses, Gordon comes face to face with stronger and stronger enemies who use different tactics to bring him down. Without ever uttering a word, Gordon swings his Crowbar (or perhaps his trusted shotgun) and plows them through, persevering through yet another life-threatening situation. It is just how badass he is (you are).Most of the times though, there is a lot of button-pushing in this game. Luckily, this is where the M.I.T-graduation comes in handy - for who could ever push a button the way M.I.T graduates can? Jokes aside though, he is darn fast at climbing ladders (while holding his crowbar with two hands - how does he do it?)!Personally, I really enjoy this game through and through. The Source engine allows for some slick movement and fast-paced gaming. If you take your time to listen to random scientists, you may or may not be surprised to hear that many of them are just as human as you and me. This is something that adds to the game and integrates the player further into the story, in my opinion. The story is great and the enemies have very advanced A.I for the time (1998, remember - that's 16 years ago!). I would recommend this game for every and any player who has ever played FPS-games, but even more so to any Quake, Doom or Unreal Tournament fans out there. So come on, give it a spin - it'll be worth it!

content:
r 1, 2016
												A masterpiece. One of the best first person shooters ever made IMO.The game's highest point is easily its immersion, almost unrivaled even until today, gripping you with its atmosphere and actually putting you in the shoes of a (sort of) Average Joe, who's unlucky enough to be at the wrong place at the wrong time. No cutscenes, no quick time events, no regenerating health, no objective markers cluttering up the screen or excessive handholding, no annoying constant remarks by the protagonist (tbh some games can do a talking protag right, but in this game I feel that a silent protag was perfect for it and used really well), and you're almost never taken away control of Freeman. This all combines with a great setting oozing with atmosphere, memorable enemies such as the headcrab, scripted events that are done in a very natural way to give life to the game world and that trigger often as you explore a space in an organic fashion, lots of environmental storytelling that rewards the player for sticking around to search and listen but doesn't force them to stop, and excellent level design with enough searching and nooks and crannies to explore to not give the feeling of being on rails that other linear games give. It really lets you live and experience the game, not just watch it like a semi-interactive movie as so many modern first person shooters now do.From a more gameplay-wise perspective, the weapons are rather fun to use and enemy AI is surprisingly still decent to this day and age, especially the amazing marine AI. You amass a very large arsenal of around 14 weapons, none feeling superfluous or excessively powerful and all surprisingly balanced and functional, each with their own situational ups and downs. No regenerating health naturally encourages you to be on the move and explore, in search of health packs and health stations (this is definately something you want in an FPS, as instead of the stale taking cover all the time to regen health of other games, you're encouraged to play far more dynamically and actually go out there, move and dodge, scavenge and explore). Movement isn't perfect, it can at times be too sensitive, but the speed but definately far faster and more fluid than the average CoD running speed that feels like you have bowling balls for feet.Cons? Well, if I had to point out problems with the game, then probably the Xen levels, aka the final few levels of the game. The physics in those levels are horrible and really frustrating, the level designs are bad and not fun to play through, and it's mostly a rather disappointing and frustrating last stretch of levels in an otherwise masterpiece game.Overall, 9.5/10, without Xen it would be 10/10, and either way it's a must play for any FPS fan.

												This game should be played by anyone who consider himself a PC gamer. This total classic built the base for a lot of modern shooters. It has a great story and graphics for the time, some characters are funny as hell and the gameplay is phenomenal. It has an unparalleled replayability because of the endless places to play online with a lot of people that still play it, and dozens of free mods here on Steam and elsewhere, which are whole new different experiences (basically different games with their story). The soundtrack is atmospheric and its a variety of weapons, from a crowbar to a rocket launcher keep you interested. Classic cutscenes and memorable levels. Wait for a steam sale and grab it! It deserves your attention. 9/10  Nominated for the “Test of Time” Award

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
r 18, 2015
												The origin of everyone's favourite crowbar-wielding, vent-crawling theoretical physicist. This game is amazing, in nearly every way. The level design is clever and intuitive, cleverly directing you between objectives without the use of floating arrows or map markers. Every level feels visually distinct, and the difficulty curve is well-balanced and ramps up steadily throughout the game. Half-Life's story is simple but engrossing, and is told without ever taking away player control. The pacing is extremely well-done, striking a good balance between firefights, exploring, and environmental puzzles. Jumping physics are solid, and the platforming sections are never frustrating (don't forget to quick-save before a tricky jump!). Guns and weapons handle well and feel powerful. Health and ammo pick-ups are well-spaced, providing enough tension caused by resource scarcity, but avoiding frustratingly long stretches of having low health or no ammo. The sound design is incredible, whether it's the sound of Gordon's footsteps on a metal grate, the moans of a headcrab zombie, or the resounding "BOOM!" of a shotgun.

content:
er 2, 2013
												This is the game that started it all.The thing is,it still holds up;I spent hours and hours playing and replaying this game for the different kinds of actual challenges it offers.You can go up against crazy bosses AND skirmishes with lots of little guys,navigate the terrain and some of the fights with really good twitch reflexes and learning how the level works,old-school arcade style,plus,while it isn't a puzzler,you really do have to think about your environment and figure out how to use it to survive.When they talk about"a workout for your whole brain derp derp"in anything,this is kind of using your whole gaming brain,and it's satisfying.You kind of forget how polygonal and 1990s the graphics are with how richly the world is imagined,and you really do get a sense of Gordon Freeman as a lone,lucky survivor who evolves into a BAMF by natural selection.I do want to say,it's very different from the HL2 games;those are more talky and give us a less isolated Gordon.While you don't get the gravity gun in this game,I found myself wishing for some of the cool weapons available in this game in HL2.I will venture to say that you can't really call yourself an FPS player until you've played HL1.;-)

content:
y 16, 2014
 Half-Life What is there to say about this game? Well actually, alot. This game is absolutely fantastic. Personally, I prefer it over 2. Anyways, with my opinion out of the way, I'm going to elaborate about why this game is so  great.  The story starts with you, Gordon Freeman. The 27 year old scientist with a degree in Theoretical Physics. Not much to say about that. Your workplace, Black Mesa, gets attacked by various aliens and the marines when an transfer goes wrong. The thing about this game is that theres a huge element of surprise. You'll find out what I mean when you play the game. Yea.Plot twists, man.Anyways, the gameplay. That makes the whole game. The gameplay is absolutely fantastic for an FPS. However, this isn't just any FPS with some macho guy ripping monster heads off because it's fun (I'm looking at you, Duke Nukem.)This is, what I would call an action-adventure FPS. This game really set the standard for the genre. There's a fair assortment of weapons. Speaking of weapons, you're going to need ammo. Alot of it.That's not necessarily a bad thing - it's everywhere. Or atleast, it's not very hard to find ammo. The other thing with this game is that, you, the player needs to be very patient. This game has backtracking. Alot of it. Next thing, the graphics. The graphics aged fairly well, in my opinion. Sure, some of the models might look wonky, but it can be easily fixed with a few HD mods. There is music in this game. Although, they only really play during intense parts, it's still quite well composed.If you look past the backtracking and constant dying, you'll love this game. Trust me.It's absolutely fantastic, and really set the standards for the FPS genre after 1998. That's not all I have to say about Half-Life, but if I did, you and I would be here all day. Final Verdict:9.5/10 An absolute fantabulous masterpiece
